Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of High Performance Computer Cluster for Multidisciplinary Computational Research and Education

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project, acquiring a high performance computer cluster, aims to enable discipline-specific and inter-disciplinary computing intensive scientific research in the areas of, but not limited to, chemical physics, material science, bioinformatics, ecological research, genomic research, morphological sciences, ocean modeling, mathematical cognition analysis, and many more. It will also be used for the education of new generation computational researchers. The instrument will be used by more than 12-faculty members from Physics, Mathematics, Biological Sciences, Materials Engineering, Psychology and Community Health, and, will impact hundreds of students in the STEM disciplines.

Numerous discipline-specific and interdisciplinary research programs will leverage this instrument to further their research goals. Efforts in computational chemical physics provide insights into new mechanisms to improve combustion modeling. Materials modeling, methods and software development will generate improved ways to model device failures. Microfiltration, nanofluidics research, and, 3D ocean modeling will advance oil exploration research. High-throughput annotation and analysis of large-scale microbial ecology data will provide insight into the role of gut microbes in human health, and prediction models for craniofacial growth will improve current practices within clinical orthodontics. This instrument strongly impacts the integration of research into STEM education, thus, providing an intellectual platform for researchers and students. The cluster will be the primary educational tool for WSU's newly developed Interdisciplinary Applied Science and Mathematics PhD program, potentially impacting hundreds of students at both the undergraduate and graduate levels across many disciplines. It will be the first of its kind in the Dayton region to provide education and training on the basic tools and techniques of multiprocessor computing for computational scientists A student-centered, research-based, pragmatic multi-disciplinary course, co-taught by the proposal team, based on an investigative learning approach will provide an educational platform for teaching computational concepts and tools for applying numerical methods in STEM research. The project contributes to developing a computationally skilled workforce, thus, building a stronger computing community at WSU and strengthening WSU's partnerships in computing education with other universities in the area. POR.DRECONTENT:
This award from the Major Research Instrumentation Program (MRI) funded the acquisition of high-performance computing cluster to support research efforts of more than 12 faculty members from the College of Science and Mathematics, and the College of Science and Engineering,  with research interests in chemical physics, material science, bioinformatics, ecological research, genomic research, morphological sciences, ocean modeling, and applied mathematics. This instrument is the primary educational tool for WSU?s newly developed Interdisciplinary Applied Science and Mathematics PhD program, and, it is available to hundreds of students at both the undergraduate and graduate level across many disciplines. 

The HPC instrument acquired through this grant is comprised of 1-Head node with (2x) Intel Ten Core Xeon E5-2640v4 2.4GHz; 128GB DDR4 RAM at 2400MHZ; 48TB, 2Gb/s Enterprise Hard Drive 7200RPM w/ 256MB Cache with hardware RAID5 configuration with over 40TB of usable disk space. 34 Compute nodes (22 with 64GB RAM and 12 with 128GB RAM) powered by (2x) Intel Ten Core Xeon E5-2640v4 2.4GHz per node, 240GB SSD and 1TB SATA Enterprise Hard Disk for local storage. The HPC cluster includes a GPU node with 2x NVIDIA Tesla P100 PCI-E 12GB GDDR5 Passive Single GPU and cpu configuration similar to the compute nodes. The Ethernet switching is used in addition to the Infiniband network for basic message-passing & cluster management whereas the InfiniBand handles the high-speed data transfer between nodes.

This instrument has been used to support various computational course taught at undergraduate and graduate level, namely, undergraduate course on "Scientific Computing with Python" for freshmen physics majors; graduate level course on "Applications of Parallel Computing"; graduate level course on the current state-of-the-art techniques and computational approaches in the different fields of systems biology including genomics, transcriptomics, proteomics, and metabolomics; "Scientific Computation" and "Numerical Analysis I" and "Numerical Analysis II" graduate level courses; and, course on "Computational Methods for Mechanical Engineering".

The HPC cluster has been instrumental in many research projects from many researchers and students at WSU. We will only list few major achievements as the list is too long to list all the scientific research outcomes supported by this instrument. The research supported by the HPC cluster has resulted in numerous publications, and, graduate, undergraduate students have acquired computational and HPC skills while working on computational research projects at WSU.

Prof. Sulman, formulated adaptive moving mesh methods with finite difference and finite element discretization to compute solutions for chemotaxis models: Keller-Segel and cancer invasion models. The adaptive methods were able to capture the solutions blow-up behavior and sharp, spiky features that appeared in the solution profiles of the cancer invasion models. Furthermore, the moving mesh methods use less resolution in comparison to uniform grid methods. Positivity preserving techniques was used to conserve the physical properties and maintain the stability of physical solutions.

Prof. Priezjev?s research focuses on understanding and characterization of porous structures in variety of applications including adsorption, catalysis, separation, oil and gas extrusion, and biomedical implants ? studies influence of periodic shear on structural relaxation and pore redistribution in binary glasses. Atomic configuration (each 300,000 atoms) is constructed for different loading cycles to compute the pore-occupiable volume, pore size distributions, total pore surface area, diameter of the largest included sphere using large scale molecular dynamics simulations.

Prof. Sharma, published ab-initio potential energy surfaces for the study of line shapes of optically pumped rare gas lasers and alkali-rare gas lasers. This work has been conducted in collaboration with Air Force Institute of Technology (AFIT), where experimental efforts use the potential energy manifolds for the emitter gas atom and collider system to determine rate constants for energy transfer and quenching, and, for the determination of shifting and collision broadening of spectral line profiles.  The molecular potential energy surfaces are calculated using Multiconfiguration Self Consistent Field (MCSCF) approach followed by all electron Multi-Reference Configuration Interaction (MRCI) method and Spin-Orbit approach. NSF funded computational resources were used for large scale, high-accuracy first principle calculations.
